content.raw:
Adding a `const` to a value parameter of a function declaration doesn’t have any effect on the function’s signature. Classes that override this function can choose to add or remove the const, and there’s nothing we can do about it.

The recommended practice from Clang and MSVC compiler developers is to leave off the const on value parameters in function declarations \(because it adds “noise” to your declaration without having literally any effect\), but do include the const in the function definition whenever it’s desired.
content.html:
Adding a const to a value parameter of a function declaration doesn’t have any effect on the function’s signature. Classes that override this function can choose to add or remove the const, and there’s nothing we can do about it.

The recommended practice from Clang and MSVC compiler developers is to leave off the const on value parameters in function declarations (because it adds “noise” to your declaration without having literally any effect), but do include the const in the function definition whenever it’s desired.
